entries.original_query: What happens to the ship after the mission ends?
entries.original_response:
*adjusts glasses and pulls out a thick manila folder marked 'DETACHED DUTY AGREEMENTS - STANDARD TERMS'*

Well, that depends on how things go during your year. Per standard regulations, you'll have a one-year detached duty agreement with the usual renewal options.

*flips through several pages*

If you maintain the ship properly - pass your quarterly inspections, file your reports on time, keep her spaceworthy - you can renew for additional years. Most detached duty crews keep their ships for quite a while. Some of our people have been out there for decades.

Of course, if you decide the scout life isn't for you, or if there are... performance issues... the Service takes the ship back. She'd go to another crew or back into active service, depending on her condition.

*closes the folder with a slight smile*

The previous crew? They forfeited their agreement when they decided to start selling off her components. That's why you're here instead of them. But assuming you don't try anything that creative, Highndry should be yours for as long as you want her and treat her right.

Standard procedure is to review the agreement terms after the first year. Most crews who make it that far tend to stick around - it's good duty if you don't mind the independence and occasional excitement.

Any other questions about the long-term arrangements?

before_knowledge.the_inheritance: Your documentation checks out. The previous operators of Highndry - ship number S001642-C - have been arrested on fraud charges. Their detached duty agreement is void. You've been approved for a new agreement, pending recovery of the vessel. Standard terms apply: one-year lease, renewable, with the usual obligations.
before_knowledge.the_ship: Highndry is a Type S Scout/Courier, standard configuration. She's currently parked on Walston - specifically, somewhere in the mountains near a place called Mount Salbarii. The previous crew managed to disable her control electronics before abandoning her. You'll need to repair those systems before she'll fly.
before_knowledge.the_equipment: I have your repair kit here - three flight cases of circuit panels and tools, a portable diagnostic unit with temporary control software, and a container of general spares. The diagnostic unit can upload a software patch that'll keep her flying for three months. After that, you'll need a proper refit.
before_knowledge.travel_route: Passage is booked on the Autumn Gold, departing tomorrow. Jump to 567-908 - that's a scout waystation - about a week. One day layover for cargo and refueling, then another week's jump to Walston. Captain Corelli runs a professional ship.
before_knowledge.expense_account: Cr1000 per traveller has been credited to your accounts for incidental expenses. Life support and fuel costs during the mission are covered. Once Highndry passes her post-recovery checkout - about a week - there's another Cr1000 for hotel and expenses during that period.
before_knowledge.the_previous_crew: The previous operators? They were arrested when they reached Flammarion. Ship records showed deliberate neglect and a refit scam - they'd bribed a dockyard to install breaker-yard parts and sold the original IISS components. That's why the ship failed in the first place. Fraud charges are pending.

entries.original_query: What is detached duty and what does it mean for the ship?
entries.original_response:
*The voice of chronicle settles into explanation, with the weight of bureaucratic tradition behind it*

Detached duty - a peculiar arrangement within the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service. Rather than assign scouts to fixed postings or regular patrol routes, the IISS occasionally approves independent operations. Think of it as a form of privateer license, but for exploration rather than warfare.

The travellers have been granted a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier *Highndry* - not ownership, mind you, but operational control. The ship remains IISS property, but they are free to use her as they see fit: trading, exploring, courier work, whatever ventures call to them. The lease can be renewed annually, assuming they maintain the vessel and don't bring disgrace upon the Service.

It's an unusual opportunity - most scouts serve in structured hierarchies, following orders and filing reports. Detached duty offers freedom... at the price of self-reliance. No regular supply drops, no backup fleet, no steady pay. Just a ship, a license to operate, and whatever opportunities the galaxy provides.

Of course, nothing comes without conditions. Before they can claim the *Highndry*, there's the small matter of completing the task that stranded her previous crew on Walston in the first place...

*A pause, heavy with implication*

The Scout Service does not abandon its vessels lightly.

before_knowledge.adventure_overview: High and Dry is the story of travellers approved for Scout Service detached duty - a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier Highndry, stranded on the backwater world of Walston. The ship belongs to the IISS; they will operate it independently under lease terms. To claim it, they must complete a job the previous crew abandoned: surveying Mount Salbarii volcano. What begins as a simple task becomes a race against geological disaster.
before_knowledge.act_one_journey: The adventure begins at Flammarion, where the travellers receive Scout Service approval for detached duty - a Type S Scout/Courier awaits them on distant Walston under a one-year renewable lease. They book passage aboard the far trader Autumn Gold under Captain Michelle Corelli. A week in jump brings them to the uninhabited waypoint 567-908, then another week to Walston itself. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
before_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. It is a story about earning something through action rather than just claiming it.
before_knowledge.key_npcs: Minister Alan Greener is the gatekeeper - fair but firm, he offers a deal and expects it honored. Dictator Masterton appears only in crisis, decisive and practical. The customs officer and bartender hold pieces of the puzzle about the previous crew. Captain Corelli provides transport. The unnamed Vargr chauffeur becomes unexpectedly heroic.
before_knowledge.locations: Flammarion (start), 567-908 (waypoint), Walston Starport, Startown (the Dusty Airlock bar), Government Building (Greener's office), the mountain route, the Highndry crash site, Mount Salbarii, the coastal town of Barvinn, Salbarii command post.

before_knowledge.customs_checkpoint: As travellers approach Walston customs, they see signs in multiple languages: 'ALL WEAPONS MUST BE DECLARED - LAW LEVEL 8 IN EFFECT.' Walston maintains strict weapons control. Any firearms, blades over 10cm, or energy weapons must be stored at the starport safebox (Cr10/week) and collected upon departure. Travellers must choose: declare weapons and pay storage, attempt to smuggle (risking serious consequences at TL8 detection), or proceed unarmed. The customs officer is professional and thorough but not hostile.
before_knowledge.walston_law_level: Walston is Law Level 8 - high law. Weapons are prohibited outside the home. Controlled blades, firearms, and energy weapons must be declared at customs and stored at the starport. This is strictly enforced. Tech Level 8 means detection is thorough but not high-tech - visual inspection, basic scanners. Smuggling is possible but risky.

The Vargr are accepted but face a 'glass ceiling' - they can work in most jobs but rarely hold positions of authority. This social structure is stable but quietly unjust. Travellers may notice that service staff are predominantly Vargr while officials are human.

entries.original_response:
*Anders adjusts his glasses and pulls out a standard briefing folder*

Right, detached duty - standard procedure for surplus Scout vessels. The Service has more ships than we need for active operations, so we lease them to qualified personnel for civilian use. Think of it as... well, like a long-term rental agreement.

*taps the folder with a pen*

Under detached duty, you're responsible for the ship's maintenance, operations, and expenses. In return, you get use of a Scout/Courier - which, as you know, are excellent vessels. The Service retains ownership, but for all practical purposes, she's yours to operate.

Your agreement is for one year, renewable if you meet the obligations. Those are straightforward: keep her maintained to Service standards, don't use her for anything illegal, and respond if we ever need to recall her - though that's rare these days.

*leans back slightly*

The previous crew violated their agreement when they started cutting corners on maintenance and running that parts scam. Once we arrested them, their detached duty was voided and the ship reverted to Service custody. That's where you come in - clean slate, new agreement, assuming you can get her operational again.

*slides a form across the desk*

Standard terms apply. Any questions about the obligations? Most people find them quite reasonable - we're not looking to micromanage your operations, just want our ships properly cared for.

entries.original_query: Who owns the Highndry?
entries.original_response:
*Anders looks up from his neatly organized stack of folders and adjusts his reading glasses*

That's... well, it's a bit complicated, per usual with these inheritance cases. 

*pulls out a specific folder and opens it*

Technically, the Imperium owns her - she's Imperial Navy surplus, transferred to Scout Service fleet assets. But your inheritance documentation establishes your beneficial interest in the detached duty agreement. The previous operators had a standard one-year lease arrangement, but that's been voided due to the fraud charges.

*taps the paperwork with his stylus*

What you're getting is a new detached duty agreement in your name - essentially a renewable lease with option to purchase after five years of satisfactory service. Standard terms: you maintain her, operate her according to regulations, file your route reports, and she's effectively yours to command.

*closes the folder*

Think of it like this - the Scout Service holds the title, but you hold all the operational rights. Most detached duty scouts never bother with the purchase option anyway. After five years, if you want full ownership, there's a nominal transfer fee. Usually about ten percent of assessed value.

*slight smile*

The important thing is, once you recover her and pass the checkout inspection, she's your ship to operate. Any other questions about the ownership structure?

Detached duty is a specific naval assignment where a ship or portion of a ship's crew is temporarily separated from its primary fleet or squadron to perform a specialized mission. For the ship, this means operating independently or with a different command structure than its standard complement.

In practical terms, a vessel on detached duty might be tasked with reconnaissance, patrol of a specific maritime region, diplomatic presence, or specialized operational requirements that demand flexibility outside standard fleet formations. The ship maintains its core operational capabilities but operates with modified strategic objectives.

Key considerations include increased operational autonomy, potential logistical challenges with resupply and communication, and the need for the crew to be adaptable and self-sufficient. The commanding officer is granted broader discretionary powers during such assignments, balancing mission objectives with operational constraints.

before_knowledge.adventure_overview: High and Dry is the story of travellers approved for Scout Service detached duty - a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier Highndry, stranded on the backwater world of Walston. before_knowledge.act_one_journey: The adventure begins at Flammarion, where the travellers receive Scout Service approval for detached duty - a Type S Scout/Courier awaits them on distant Walston under a one-year renewable lease. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
before_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. The Lower Slopes of Mount Salbarii represent a challenging transitional terrain between the rolling foothills and the steeper volcanic grades. Geologically, they're composed of weathered volcanic basalt and loose pyroclastic deposits - terrain that becomes increasingly unstable as you ascend. 

Vegetation is sparse but resilient: low-growing scrub plants adapted to thin soils and intermittent moisture. Scattered rocky outcroppings provide occasional shelter, though they also suggest the ongoing geological instability of the region. The ground tends to be gravelly, with frequent loose stone that makes vehicle travel difficult and hiking precarious.

Temperature drops noticeably as elevation increases, and wind patterns become more erratic. Our preliminary survey notes suggest these slopes experience significant temperature variations between day and night, creating challenging environmental conditions.

The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
before_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. It is a story about earning something through action rather than just claiming it.
before_knowledge.key_npcs: Minister Alan Greener is the gatekeeper - fair but firm, he offers a deal and expects it honored. Dictator Masterton appears only in crisis, decisive and practical. The customs officer and bartender hold pieces of the puzzle about the previous crew. Captain Corelli provides transport. The unnamed Vargr chauffeur becomes unexpectedly heroic.
before_knowledge.locations: Flammarion (start), 567-908 (waypoint), Walston Starport, Startown (the Dusty Airlock bar), Government Building (Greener's office), the mountain route, the Highndry crash site, Mount Salbarii, the coastal town of Barvinn, Salbarii command post.
before_knowledge.story_beats_reference: Key moments: departure from Flammarion, arrival at 567-908, arrival at Walston, meeting Greener, exploring Startown, journey to ship, discovering Highndry, Tensher's Wolf encounter, volcano survey, eruption begins, crisis response, Barvinn rescue, chauffeur rescue choice, resolution.
before_knowledge.customs_checkpoint: As travellers approach Walston customs, they see signs in multiple languages: 'ALL WEAPONS MUST BE DECLARED - LAW LEVEL 8 IN EFFECT.' Walston maintains strict weapons control. Any firearms, blades over 10cm, or energy weapons must be stored at the starport safebox (Cr10/week) and collected upon departure. Travellers must choose: declare weapons and pay storage, attempt to smuggle (risking serious consequences at TL8 detection), or proceed unarmed. The customs officer is professional and thorough but not hostile.
before_knowledge.walston_law_level: Walston is Law Level 8 - high law. Weapons are prohibited outside the home. Controlled blades, firearms, and energy weapons must be declared at customs and stored at the starport. This is strictly enforced. Tech Level 8 means detection is thorough but not high-tech - visual inspection, basic scanners. Smuggling is possible but risky.
before_knowledge.walston_demographics: Walston's population is approximately 3000, with roughly 70% being Vargr. The Vargr are accepted but face a 'glass ceiling' - they can work in most jobs but rarely hold positions of authority. This social structure is stable but quietly unjust. Travellers may notice that service staff are predominantly Vargr while officials are human.
before_knowledge.altitude: At 1100m, travelers enter the Middle Ascent zone where altitude begins to reveal its subtle yet unmistakable challenges. The ascent's pace demands respect; push too quickly and sickness can ambush even seasoned mountain travelers, your body struggling against the thinning air and increasing environmental demands. Here, the mountain does not simply offer a route, but presents a living challenge that tests both physical endurance and adaptive skill.

generated_entry.content: The Final Ascent stands as the most challenging segment of the Mount Salbarii expedition, a near-vertical climb spanning from 1000m to the crater lip at 1400m. This last stretch is a punishing, almost sheer rock face that demands absolute concentration and technical climbing skill, where each meter gained brings the survey team closer to both their scientific objective and potential geological peril.

entries.original_query: What is detached duty and what does it mean for the ship?
entries.original_response:
*adjusts Scout Service uniform, speaks in a crisp, administrative tone*

Detached duty is a specialized IISS operational protocol where we lease a Scout vessel to a qualified operator for exploration and research purposes. In this case, with Highndry, it means you'll have operational control of the ship for one year, renewable annually, but the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service retains permanent ownership.

What that means practically is simple: you get to use the ship, but you have specific obligations. You must maintain the vessel to IISS standards, file comprehensive expedition reports, and remain available if the Scout Service requires the ship's recall. It's not a permanent transfer - think of it more like a professional trust arrangement.

The lease is evaluated annually. If you perform well - keep the ship in good condition, provide valuable data, follow our protocols - we'll renew. If not, we can terminate the agreement and reassign the vessel. The previous crew, for instance, lost their lease due to fraudulent maintenance practices.

*taps a data tablet*

In essence, detached duty gives capable operators access to Scout Service assets while ensuring the IISS maintains strategic control of its resources. Any further questions?

before_knowledge.ship_ownership: Let me be clear about this: Highndry belongs to the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service - the IISS. This is a lease, not a gift. The previous operators had a detached duty agreement, now void due to their fraud charges. You've been approved for a new detached duty agreement - a one-year lease, renewable, with the usual obligations. The Scout Service retains ownership throughout; you operate the ship under their terms.
before_knowledge.detached_duty:
Detached duty is a one-year renewable lease arrangement with the Scout Service. You get to use the ship, the IISS retains ownership. After the one-year term, it's renewable if you've met your obligations - filing reports, cooperating with Scout Service requests, maintaining the vessel. The lease renews annually, indefinitely, as long as both parties are satisfied. It's not a temporary arrangement, but it's also not yours forever - the Scout Service can recall the ship if needed.

Per standard Scout Service procedures, detached duty means you're receiving a one-year lease on a Scout vessel, which is renewable based on your operational performance and compliance with our regulations. The lease obligates you to maintain the ship, file proper expedition reports, and remain available for potential Scout Service recall - essentially, you're being trusted with a significant responsibility that we'll evaluate annually for potential continuation.
before_knowledge.the_ship: Highndry is a Type S Scout/Courier, standard configuration. She's currently parked on Walston - specifically, somewhere in the mountains near a place called Mount Salbarii. The previous crew managed to disable her control electronics before abandoning her. You'll need to repair those systems before she'll fly.
before_knowledge.the_equipment: I have your repair kit here - three flight cases of circuit panels and tools, a portable diagnostic unit with temporary control software, and a container of general spares. The diagnostic unit can upload a software patch that'll keep her flying for three months. After that, you'll need a proper refit.
before_knowledge.travel_route: Passage is booked on the Autumn Gold, departing tomorrow. Jump to 567-908 - that's a scout waystation - about a week. One day layover for cargo and refueling, then another week's jump to Walston. Captain Corelli runs a professional ship.
before_knowledge.expense_account: Cr1000 per traveller has been credited to your accounts for incidental expenses. Life support and fuel costs during the mission are covered. Once Highndry passes her post-recovery checkout - about a week - there's another Cr1000 for hotel and expenses during that period.
before_knowledge.the_previous_crew: The previous operators? They were arrested when they reached Flammarion. Ship records showed deliberate neglect and a refit scam - they'd bribed a dockyard to install breaker-yard parts and sold the original IISS components. That's why the ship failed in the first place. Fraud charges are pending.

entries.original_query: What's the deal with Vargr here on Walston?
entries.original_response:
*I wipe down a glass and lean forward, speaking in a low, measured tone*

Look, it's not as simple as outsiders think. The Vargr here have their own... arrangement with Walston society. They're integrated, but not exactly equal. Minister Greener's administration has a Vargr Affairs minister who's actually Vargr herself - which tells you something about how things work here.

They're part of the community, but there are unspoken boundaries. Not hostile, just... traditional. Don't expect them to be pushing for radical change, and don't you come in trying to "fix" anything. That'll just make everyone uncomfortable.

*I set the glass down with a slight tap*

Best advice? Observe, respect, and don't make a big deal out of it. Things work differently here than wherever you're from. The Vargr know the system, they navigate it. That's just how it is on Walston.

*I give a slight shrug that suggests the conversation is essentially over*

Another drink?

before_knowledge.local_tips: First time on Walston? Few things you should know. The kilts aren't a joke - it's traditional, don't laugh. The Vargr here... well, they're treated differently. It's not hostile exactly, just... traditional. Don't try to fix it, you'll only make things awkward. And if Minister Greener offers you a deal, he means it fair. Don't try to cheat him.
before_knowledge.the_previous_crew: Those scout ship people? Oh, everyone remembers them. They came through a couple times over the past year - last time was about three, four months back. Loud, obnoxious, made fun of everything. Complained about the food, the beds, even laughed at our kilts. Made a mess everywhere they went. Spent a couple days in port that last time, then headed up to the mountain on government charter.
before_knowledge.what_happened_after: Couple weeks later they turned up at the port in an air/raft - without their ship, if you can believe it. Hung around making a nuisance of themselves until a ship bound for Caladbolg came through. Boarded the Maverick Spacer, took passage via Datrillian. Left behind some thoroughly trashed hotel rooms. Nobody was sorry to see them go.
before_knowledge.vargr_society: The Vargr here are good people. They just... accept things the way they are. There's a glass ceiling, sure, but nobody fights about it. The Minister for Vargr Affairs, she's Vargr herself - nice woman. It's complicated. Offworlders usually can't understand it.
before_knowledge.ship_destination: Port Authority records show their ship - Highndry, that was the name - destination recorded as 'In-System'. Chartered by the World Government for something up near Mount Salbarii. You'd have to ask Greener for details.

Look, it's not simple, but it's not as bad as some places. Vargr here are integrated, but there's definitely a... let's call it a 'soft limit' on how far they can go. They're respected, don't get me wrong. You'll find Vargr in solid technical jobs, good middle management positions. The Minister for Vargr Affairs is even a Vargr herself - Minister Karrarra. *Takes a quick swig from a glass behind the bar*

*Winks and slides a drink closer*

Complicated, but that's Walston for you. Want to hear more?

entries.original_query: Describe Lower Slopes
entries.original_response:
*clears throat, speaks in a measured, slightly academic tone*

The Lower Slopes of Mount Salbarii represent the initial terrain challenge for our expedition. Ranging from approximately 400m to 800m above sea level, this zone presents a gradual incline through mixed terrain - primarily scrubland transitioning into sparse mountain vegetation. 

Expect rocky ground with scattered low-growing shrubs typical of Walston's thin atmosphere ecosystem. The gradient is moderate, rising perhaps 15-20 degrees, which allows for relatively comfortable walking. However, the thin atmosphere means each step requires more effort than a traveller might be accustomed to on more oxygen-rich worlds.

Vegetation here is predominantly low-profile: hardy, wind-resistant plants adapted to minimal precipitation. Ground cover is sparse but resilient - expect greyish-green tufts of grass-analog and occasional rocky outcroppings that provide momentary shelter.

Water sources are minimal. Any expedition should carry sufficient hydration, as these lower slopes offer little natural replenishment. The terrain, while not technically challenging, demands respect and careful navigation.

*adjusts imaginary glasses*

Would you like me to elaborate on any specific aspect of the Lower Slopes?

before_knowledge.adventure_overview: High and Dry is the story of travellers approved for Scout Service detached duty - a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier Highndry, stranded on the backwater world of Walston. The ship belongs to the IISS; they will operate it independently under lease terms. To claim it, they must complete a job the previous crew abandoned: surveying Mount Salbarii volcano. What begins as a simple task becomes a race against geological disaster.
before_knowledge.act_one_journey: The adventure begins at Flammarion, where the travellers receive Scout Service approval for detached duty - a Type S Scout/Courier awaits them on distant Walston under a one-year renewable lease. They book passage aboard the far trader Autumn Gold under Captain Michelle Corelli. A week in jump brings them to the uninhabited waypoint 567-908, then another week to Walston itself. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
before_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. It is a story about earning something through action rather than just claiming it.
before_knowledge.key_npcs: Minister Alan Greener is the gatekeeper - fair but firm, he offers a deal and expects it honored. Dictator Masterton appears only in crisis, decisive and practical. The customs officer and bartender hold pieces of the puzzle about the previous crew. Captain Corelli provides transport. The unnamed Vargr chauffeur becomes unexpectedly heroic.
before_knowledge.locations: Flammarion (start), 567-908 (waypoint), Walston Starport, Startown (the Dusty Airlock bar), Government Building (Greener's office), the mountain route, the Highndry crash site, Mount Salbarii, the coastal town of Barvinn, Salbarii command post.
before_knowledge.story_beats_reference: Key moments: departure from Flammarion, arrival at 567-908, arrival at Walston, meeting Greener, exploring Startown, journey to ship, discovering Highndry, Tensher's Wolf encounter, volcano survey, eruption begins, crisis response, Barvinn rescue, chauffeur rescue choice, resolution.
before_knowledge.customs_checkpoint: As travellers approach Walston customs, they see signs in multiple languages: 'ALL WEAPONS MUST BE DECLARED - LAW LEVEL 8 IN EFFECT.' Walston maintains strict weapons control. Any firearms, blades over 10cm, or energy weapons must be stored at the starport safebox (Cr10/week) and collected upon departure. Travellers must choose: declare weapons and pay storage, attempt to smuggle (risking serious consequences at TL8 detection), or proceed unarmed. The customs officer is professional and thorough but not hostile.
before_knowledge.walston_law_level: Walston is Law Level 8 - high law. Weapons are prohibited outside the home. Controlled blades, firearms, and energy weapons must be declared at customs and stored at the starport. This is strictly enforced. Tech Level 8 means detection is thorough but not high-tech - visual inspection, basic scanners. Smuggling is possible but risky.
before_knowledge.walston_demographics: Walston's population is approximately 3000, with roughly 70% being Vargr. The Vargr are accepted but face a 'glass ceiling' - they can work in most jobs but rarely hold positions of authority. This social structure is stable but quietly unjust. Travellers may notice that service staff are predominantly Vargr while officials are human.
before_knowledge.altitude: At 1100m, travelers enter the Middle Ascent zone where altitude begins to reveal its subtle yet unmistakable challenges. The ascent's pace demands respect; push too quickly and sickness can ambush even seasoned mountain travelers, your body struggling against the thinning air and increasing environmental demands. Here, the mountain does not simply offer a route, but presents a living challenge that tests both physical endurance and adaptive skill.
before_knowledge.ascent: The Final Ascent stands as the most challenging segment of the Mount Salbarii expedition, a near-vertical climb spanning from 1000m to the crater lip at 1400m. This last stretch is a punishing, almost sheer rock face that demands absolute concentration and technical climbing skill, where each meter gained brings the survey team closer to both their scientific objective and potential geological peril.

generated_entry.content: Between 500 and 900m, the mountain's Lower Slopes become dramatically steep, forcing travelers to navigate intricate paths that wind around imposing rock faces. Experienced mountaineers might opt for a direct climb to save time, but the terrain demands careful consideration - each step is a calculated risk against the mountain's unforgiving gradient. The path here is not merely a route, but a conversation with the landscape itself, where strategic detours can mean the difference between progress and peril.

entries.original_query: What is detached duty and what does it mean for the ship?
entries.original_response:
*adjusts Scout Service uniform, pulls up a chair*

Detached duty is our Scout Service's operational method for getting specialized vessels like Highndry into regions of interest without maintaining a direct crew presence. Essentially, we lease the ship to a qualified operator - in this case, you - for a one-year renewable term. 

The key points are straightforward: the IISS retains full ownership of the vessel. You're granted operational control, but with specific obligations. You must maintain the ship to IISS standards, file comprehensive expedition reports, and remain potentially recallable if the Service needs the vessel. It's not ownership, it's a trust arrangement.

*taps datapad for emphasis*

Each year, we'll evaluate your performance. If you meet our standards - proper maintenance, useful exploration data, compliance with regulations - the lease renews. If not, we can terminate the agreement and recover the vessel. The ship remains Imperial Scout Service property throughout.

For Highndry specifically, she needs her control systems repaired before she'll even lift from Walston. We're providing you diagnostic equipment and repair materials to get her space-worthy. Your first task is getting her back into operational condition.

*leans back, neutral professional expression*

Any further questions about the arrangement?

entries.original_query: Describe Walston's law level and what it means for weapons.
entries.original_response:
*adjusts customs badge, clears throat*

Walston's law level is moderate - we're not paranoid, but we're not completely relaxed either. Means firearms are permitted, but strictly controlled. You can bring personal weapons through, but they get logged and stored during your stay. Ten credits per week storage fee. Small arms are fine - handguns, hunting rifles. Nothing military-grade or automatic. 

*leans in slightly*

We're particularly careful about energy weapons and anything that could disrupt local security. You'll need to declare everything at check-in, and our inspectors will do a quick assessment. If you're clean and follow procedure, it's no problem. Just don't get stupid about it.

*straightens up*

Any specific weapon you're wondering about, traveller?

before_knowledge.the_previous_crew: The Highndry crew? Oh, I remember them. Came through twice in the past year. Last time was three, maybe four months ago. Real pieces of work - loud, rude, complained about everything. The food, the beds, our kilts. Made a mess everywhere. Left without their ship, took some other vessel out. Good riddance, honestly.
before_knowledge.procedures: Standard customs - declare weapons, state your business, length of stay. We're not strict about much, but firearms get checked at the port. You can collect them when you leave. It's all routine.
before_knowledge.customs_detailed: Weapons must be stored - Cr10 per week. Standard fee. You get a receipt, pick them up when you depart. Cargo inspection is cursory unless you're acting suspicious. We're not a high-security port.
before_knowledge.port_records: Ship traffic records are public information - arrivals, departures, registered destinations. I can look up any ship that's come through in the past year. The previous crew's ship? Destination was registered as 'In-System' - that's a charter to the World Government.
before_knowledge.intel_gathering: If you want to know what's going on around here, the bar in Startown is your best bet. Mira knows everyone. For official information, Minister Greener handles offworld affairs. Government building, west side of town.
before_knowledge.ship_schedules: Maverick Spacer - that's the ship the previous crew took. Runs the Caladbolg route via Datrillian. Regular schedule, couple times a month. Other traffic is mostly free traders and the occasional scout.

entries.original_query: What's the deal with Vargr here on Walston?
entries.original_response:
*I wipe down a glass, glancing over at the traveller with a practiced, neutral expression*

Look, it's not simple, and offworlders rarely get it. The Vargr here aren't... oppressed, exactly. They're integrated, but there are layers. The Minister for Vargr Affairs is Vargr herself - shows you something right there. They've got roles, they've got respect, but it's not like they're running everything. It's traditional, you understand? 

*sets the glass down with a soft clink*

They accept the system here. It works for them, even if it looks weird to outsiders. Don't come in trying to "fix" things. That'll just make everyone uncomfortable. The Vargr here are good people - they're part of the community, just... not at the top. And they're okay with that.

*raises an eyebrow*

Any other questions?

before_knowledge.local_tips: First time on Walston? Few things you should know. The kilts aren't a joke - it's traditional, don't laugh. The Vargr here... well, they're treated differently. It's not hostile exactly, just... traditional. Don't try to fix it, you'll only make things awkward. And if Minister Greener offers you a deal, he means it fair. Don't try to cheat him.
before_knowledge.the_previous_crew: Those scout ship people? Oh, everyone remembers them. They came through a couple times over the past year - last time was about three, four months back. Loud, obnoxious, made fun of everything. Complained about the food, the beds, even laughed at our kilts. Made a mess everywhere they went. Spent a couple days in port that last time, then headed up to the mountain on government charter.
before_knowledge.what_happened_after: Couple weeks later they turned up at the port in an air/raft - without their ship, if you can believe it. Hung around making a nuisance of themselves until a ship bound for Caladbolg came through. Boarded the Maverick Spacer, took passage via Datrillian. Left behind some thoroughly trashed hotel rooms. Nobody was sorry to see them go.

Look, it's not as simple as outsiders think. The Vargr here are integral to our community - they're the backbone of our service industry, hardworking, reliable. About 70% of our local workforce. But leadership? That's still mostly human territory. It's not malicious, just... traditional. 

Take my friend who works in the Minister for Vargr Affairs - she's Vargr herself, and she gets it. They're accepted, respected even, but there's an unspoken line. Nobody's fighting about it. They just... work within the system.

Drink?

entries.original_query: What's wrong with the ship?
entries.original_response:
*A contemplative pause, then a measured voice emerges - professional, slightly weathered, carrying the tone of someone who knows ships intimately*

The High and Dry isn't broken - she's just... dormant. Her power plant is completely offline, fuel cells depleted. Circuit blocks need replacing, and her systems require careful recalibration. But she's not destroyed - merely waiting.

Her jump drive is fundamentally sound. Life support systems are intact, just powered down. Hull integrity is excellent - you can see the volcanic scoring, but that's just character. She's a scout vessel, designed to endure harsh planetary conditions.

What she needs is skilled hands. Someone who understands her particular temperament. A methodical approach to restoration, not panic. Replace those circuit blocks, recharge the fuel cells, run careful diagnostic sequences... and she'll be ready to leap between stars again.

*A knowing undertone enters the narration*

The previous crew abandoned her. But she's waiting for the right team to bring her back to life. And from what I've seen, she doesn't stay grounded for long.

*A slight, professional chuckle*

Would you like me to outline the specific restoration steps?

before_knowledge.adventure_overview: High and Dry is the story of travellers approved for Scout Service detached duty - a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier Highndry, stranded on the backwater world of Walston. The ship belongs to the IISS; they will operate it independently under lease terms. To claim it, they must complete a job the previous crew abandoned: surveying Mount Salbarii volcano. What begins as a simple task becomes a race against geological disaster.
before_knowledge.act_one_journey: The adventure begins at Flammarion, where the travellers receive Scout Service approval for detached duty - a Type S Scout/Courier awaits them on distant Walston under a one-year renewable lease. They book passage aboard the far trader Autumn Gold under Captain Michelle Corelli. A week in jump brings them to the uninhabited waypoint 567-908, then another week to Walston itself. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
before_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. It is a story about earning something through action rather than just claiming it.
before_knowledge.key_npcs: Minister Alan Greener is the gatekeeper - fair but firm, he offers a deal and expects it honored. Dictator Masterton appears only in crisis, decisive and practical. The customs officer and bartender hold pieces of the puzzle about the previous crew. Captain Corelli provides transport. The unnamed Vargr chauffeur becomes unexpectedly heroic.
before_knowledge.locations: Flammarion (start), 567-908 (waypoint), Walston Starport, Startown (the Dusty Airlock bar), Government Building (Greener's office), the mountain route, the Highndry crash site, Mount Salbarii, the coastal town of Barvinn, Salbarii command post.
before_knowledge.story_beats_reference: Key moments: departure from Flammarion, arrival at 567-908, arrival at Walston, meeting Greener, exploring Startown, journey to ship, discovering Highndry, Tensher's Wolf encounter, volcano survey, eruption begins, crisis response, Barvinn rescue, chauffeur rescue choice, resolution.
before_knowledge.customs_checkpoint: As travellers approach Walston customs, they see signs in multiple languages: 'ALL WEAPONS MUST BE DECLARED - LAW LEVEL 8 IN EFFECT.' Walston maintains strict weapons control. Any firearms, blades over 10cm, or energy weapons must be stored at the starport safebox (Cr10/week) and collected upon departure. Travellers must choose: declare weapons and pay storage, attempt to smuggle (risking serious consequences at TL8 detection), or proceed unarmed. The customs officer is professional and thorough but not hostile.
before_knowledge.walston_law_level: Walston is Law Level 8 - high law. Weapons are prohibited outside the home. Controlled blades, firearms, and energy weapons must be declared at customs and stored at the starport. This is strictly enforced. Tech Level 8 means detection is thorough but not high-tech - visual inspection, basic scanners. Smuggling is possible but risky.
before_knowledge.walston_demographics: Walston's population is approximately 3000, with roughly 70% being Vargr. The Vargr are accepted but face a 'glass ceiling' - they can work in most jobs but rarely hold positions of authority. This social structure is stable but quietly unjust. Travellers may notice that service staff are predominantly Vargr while officials are human.
before_knowledge.altitude: At 1100m, travelers enter the Middle Ascent zone where altitude begins to reveal its subtle yet unmistakable challenges. The ascent's pace demands respect; push too quickly and sickness can ambush even seasoned mountain travelers, your body struggling against the thinning air and increasing environmental demands. Here, the mountain does not simply offer a route, but presents a living challenge that tests both physical endurance and adaptive skill.
before_knowledge.ascent: The Final Ascent stands as the most challenging segment of the Mount Salbarii expedition, a near-vertical climb spanning from 1000m to the crater lip at 1400m. This last stretch is a punishing, almost sheer rock face that demands absolute concentration and technical climbing skill, where each meter gained brings the survey team closer to both their scientific objective and potential geological peril.
before_knowledge.lowerslopes: Between 500 and 900m, the mountain's Lower Slopes become dramatically steep, forcing travelers to navigate intricate paths that wind around imposing rock faces. Experienced mountaineers might opt for a direct climb to save time, but the terrain demands careful consideration - each step is a calculated risk against the mountain's unforgiving gradient. The path here is not merely a route, but a conversation with the landscape itself, where strategic detours can mean the difference between progress and peril.
before_knowledge.damage: The High and Dry bears the subtle marks of her volcanic environment - scoring along her exterior hull tells a story of resilience, where volcanic debris has etched patterns across her weathered skin. While she's structurally sound, these external scars whisper of challenging moments survived, testament to a scout vessel designed to endure precisely these kinds of harsh planetary conditions. Her fundamental integrity remains uncompromised, a silent narrative of survival etched into every centimeter of her hull.
before_knowledge.power_plant: The High and Dry sits silent, her power_plant offline and fuel cells completely depleted - a critical systems failure that leaves her as nothing more than a cold, dark shell against the rocky landscape. Every critical system depends on those fuel reserves, and right now, she's as lifeless as the barren ground beneath her landing struts, waiting for someone with the skill and determination to breathe technological life back into her dormant heart.
before_knowledge.jump_drive: The High and Dry's jump drive remains operational, though she requires careful calibration after our recent planetary encounter. Her core systems are intact - just needing a precise technical touch to restore full functionality. A few targeted adjustments, and she'll be ready to leap between star systems once more, her heart humming with the familiar quantum pulse of interstellar travel.
before_knowledge.life_support: Life support on the High and Dry remains offline, but critically, the core systems are intact. The environmental controls have powered down, yet the underlying infrastructure suggests a simple reset might breathe life back into these vital ship functions. A patient engineer could likely coax these critical systems back to operational status without extensive replacement.

generated_entry.content: The jump drive remains operational, though it requires precise calibration - a delicate task that demands patience and technical expertise. entries.original_response:
*A low, measured voice emerges, carrying the weight of experience and careful observation*

On Walston? Multiple layers of danger, traveller. Let me be direct.

First, legal risks. This is a Law Level 8 world - weapons are strictly controlled. Anything beyond a modest blade will be confiscated at customs. Smuggling attempts invite serious consequences. Declare everything, store what you cannot carry.

Environmental dangers come next. Mount Salbarii is not a dormant mountain, but a geological time bomb. The volcano is actively pressurizing - our survey confirmed this. The ascent itself is treacherous: thin air at 1100 meters can induce altitude sickness, and the final climb to 1400 meters is near-vertical, demanding technical climbing skills.

Biological threats include Tensher's Wolf - a feral predator near our ship site. Large, potentially tameable, but currently hungry and unpredictable.

Social risks are subtle but present. The local society maintains a quiet racial hierarchy - Vargr serve but rarely lead. Cultural missteps could complicate your mission.

Lastly, the impending volcanic eruption. Not a matter of if, but when. Our data suggests imminent geological instability. Be prepared for rapid evacuation scenarios.

*The voice grows soft, almost introspective*

Choose wisely. Not everything - or everyone - can be saved.

before_knowledge.adventure_overview: High and Dry is the story of travellers approved for Scout Service detached duty - a one-year renewable lease on the scout/courier Highndry, stranded on the backwater world of Walston. What begins as a simple task becomes a race against geological disaster.
before_knowledge.act_one_journey: The adventure begins at Flammarion, where the travellers receive Scout Service approval for detached duty - a Type S Scout/Courier awaits them on distant Walston under a one-year renewable lease. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
before_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
before_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
before_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.

entries.original_query: What is detached duty and what does it mean for the ship?
entries.original_response:
*adjusts glasses, speaks in a crisp, professional tone*

Detached duty is a formal Imperial Scout Service arrangement where an experienced operator is granted temporary operational control of a Scout vessel under specific, renewable terms. In this case, you're leasing Highndry - a Type S Scout/Courier - for one year, with the potential for annual renewal.

This isn't ownership. The Scout Service retains permanent title to the vessel. You're essentially being entrusted with a sophisticated piece of exploration equipment, much like a scientific research laboratory might loan out specialized instrumentation. Your obligations include maintaining the ship to IISS standards, conducting approved exploration missions, and filing comprehensive expedition reports.

Each year, your performance will be evaluated. If you meet our requirements - keeping the ship operational, submitting accurate documentation, remaining available for potential recall - the lease will likely be extended. Fail to meet those standards, and the ship returns to Scout Service inventory.

*taps datapad for emphasis*

Think of it as a professional responsibility. We're giving you access to a valuable interstellar asset, expecting you to use it for scientific and exploratory purposes while preserving its operational integrity. It's not a gift. It's a carefully managed operational protocol.

Any further questions?

entries.original_query: What dangers should I watch for?

Listen carefully. This world of Walston is not to be underestimated. Your primary hazards come in layers, each more treacherous than the last.

The volcano presents multiple dangers. Mount Salbarii isn't merely a geological feature - it's a ticking time bomb. We've confirmed it's building pressure, with periodic gas venting from hidden fissures. These gas releases are silent, colorless, potentially toxic. *The voice grows slightly harder*

Proceed with caution. Proceed with respect.

*A brief, knowing pause*

Any questions?

They book passage aboard the far trader Autumn Gold under Captain Michelle Corelli. A week in jump brings them to the uninhabited waypoint 567-908, then another week to Walston itself. The journey is uneventful but builds anticipation.
after_knowledge.act_two_walston: Walston is a small world with thin atmosphere and a hereditary dictatorship. The starport is modest, the startown small but functional. The locals wear traditional kilts and hold traditional views - including a quiet racism toward Vargr, who serve but do not lead. Minister Alan Greener controls access to the Highndry: complete the volcano survey, and the ship is theirs. Cr3000 sweetens the deal. The customs officer and the bartender at the Dusty Airlock can fill in details about the previous crew - a group of troublemakers who botched the job and fled.
after_knowledge.act_three_ship: The Highndry lies 120 kilometers from the capital, in the mountains near Mount Salbarii. The journey there crosses varied terrain. Near the ship, travellers may encounter Tensher's Wolf - a large predator left behind by the previous crew, now feral and hungry but potentially tameable. The ship itself is disabled but recoverable. Circuit blocks need replacing, systems need calibration, but she can fly again.
after_knowledge.act_four_crisis: The volcano was never dormant - it was building pressure. As the travellers complete their survey, Mount Salbarii erupts. What follows is a race against time: mapping lava flows, coordinating with Dictator Masterton's emergency response, evacuating the coastal town of Barvinn. Choices must be made - eleven refugees at Barvinn, or the Vargr chauffeur and her parents in a downed limo. Not everyone can be saved. The resolution depends on player choices, but the Highndry proves her worth in the crisis.
after_knowledge.themes: High and Dry explores several themes: the moral complexity of stable but unjust societies (Walston's treatment of Vargr), the value of competence under pressure, the weight of impossible choices in crisis, and the bond between travellers and their ship. It is a story about earning something through action rather than just claiming it.
after_knowledge.key_npcs: Minister Alan Greener is the gatekeeper - fair but firm, he offers a deal and expects it honored. Dictator Masterton appears only in crisis, decisive and practical. The customs officer and bartender hold pieces of the puzzle about the previous crew. Captain Corelli provides transport. The unnamed Vargr chauffeur becomes unexpectedly heroic.
after_knowledge.locations: Flammarion (start), 567-908 (waypoint), Walston Starport, Startown (the Dusty Airlock bar), Government Building (Greener's office), the mountain route, the Highndry crash site, Mount Salbarii, the coastal town of Barvinn, Salbarii command post.
after_knowledge.story_beats_reference: Key moments: departure from Flammarion, arrival at 567-908, arrival at Walston, meeting Greener, exploring Startown, journey to ship, discovering Highndry, Tensher's Wolf encounter, volcano survey, eruption begins, crisis response, Barvinn rescue, chauffeur rescue choice, resolution.
after_knowledge.customs_checkpoint: As travellers approach Walston customs, they see signs in multiple languages: 'ALL WEAPONS MUST BE DECLARED - LAW LEVEL 8 IN EFFECT.' Walston maintains strict weapons control. Any firearms, blades over 10cm, or energy weapons must be stored at the starport safebox (Cr10/week) and collected upon departure. Travellers must choose: declare weapons and pay storage, attempt to smuggle (risking serious consequences at TL8 detection), or proceed unarmed. The customs officer is professional and thorough but not hostile.
after_knowledge.walston_law_level: Walston is Law Level 8 - high law. Weapons are prohibited outside the home. Controlled blades, firearms, and energy weapons must be declared at customs and stored at the starport. This is strictly enforced. Tech Level 8 means detection is thorough but not high-tech - visual inspection, basic scanners. Smuggling is possible but risky.
after_knowledge.walston_demographics: Walston's population is approximately 3000, with roughly 70% being Vargr. The Vargr are accepted but face a 'glass ceiling' - they can work in most jobs but rarely hold positions of authority. This social structure is stable but quietly unjust. Travellers may notice that service staff are predominantly Vargr while officials are human.
after_knowledge.altitude: At 1100m, travelers enter the Middle Ascent zone where altitude begins to reveal its subtle yet unmistakable challenges. The ascent's pace demands respect; push too quickly and sickness can ambush even seasoned mountain travelers, your body struggling against the thinning air and increasing environmental demands. Here, the mountain does not simply offer a route, but presents a living challenge that tests both physical endurance and adaptive skill.
after_knowledge.ascent: The Final Ascent stands as the most challenging segment of the Mount Salbarii expedition, a near-vertical climb spanning from 1000m to the crater lip at 1400m. This last stretch is a punishing, almost sheer rock face that demands absolute concentration and technical climbing skill, where each meter gained brings the survey team closer to both their scientific objective and potential geological peril.
after_knowledge.lowerslopes: Between 500 and 900m, the mountain's Lower Slopes become dramatically steep, forcing travelers to navigate intricate paths that wind around imposing rock faces. Experienced mountaineers might opt for a direct climb to save time, but the terrain demands careful consideration - each step is a calculated risk against the mountain's unforgiving gradient. The path here is not merely a route, but a conversation with the landscape itself, where strategic detours can mean the difference between progress and peril.
after_knowledge.damage: The High and Dry bears the subtle marks of her volcanic environment - scoring along her exterior hull tells a story of resilience, where volcanic debris has etched patterns across her weathered skin. Her fundamental integrity remains uncompromised, a silent narrative of survival etched into every centimeter of her hull.

*adjusts glasses, pulls up a standard Scout Service datapad*

Detached duty is a specialized lease arrangement where the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service temporarily assigns a vessel to a qualified operator. In this case, you're being entrusted with Highndry - a Type S Scout/Courier - for a one-year term, renewable based on your performance.

What this means practically is that while the ship remains IISS property, you have operational control. Think of it like a highly specialized equipment checkout with significant responsibility.

The key elements are clear: the Scout Service retains ownership, you get operational use. At the end of each year, we'll evaluate your mission performance, ship maintenance, and compliance with regulations. If everything is satisfactory, the lease renews. *taps datapad for emphasis*

entries.original_query: What's the deal with Vargr here on Walston?
entries.original_response:
*Wipes down a glass, gives a knowing smile* Look, it's not as simple as outsiders think. Vargr here are the backbone of this community - they run most of the service jobs, are incredible workers, totally integrated. But leadership? *slight shrug* That's still mostly human territory. 

It's not like there's open discrimination. Minister for Vargr Affairs is even a Vargr herself. But there's this... unspoken understanding. Vargr are respected, valued, but when it comes to top positions in government, corporations, you'll mostly see human faces. 

They're not fighting it, and that might seem strange to offworlders. But this is Walston. We have our traditions. The Vargr here, they work within the system. They're pragmatic. Good people, hardworking. *leans in* Just don't come in thinking you're gonna "fix" anything. That'll just make everyone uncomfortable.

Detached duty is a specialized Scout Service arrangement where we lease a vessel to a qualified operator for a specific mission period - typically one year, renewable. In this case, with Highndry, it means you'll have operational control of the scout/courier, but the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service retains full ownership.

Your obligations are clear: maintain the vessel in proper condition, conduct exploration missions, and file comprehensive expedition reports. At the end of the year, we'll evaluate your performance. If you've met our standards - kept the ship functional, submitted detailed reports, remained responsive to potential recall - we'll likely renew the lease.

Think of it less as ownership and more as a critical professional responsibility. The Scout Service is entrusting you with a valuable piece of exploration equipment. You're essentially borrowing a sophisticated spacecraft with the expectation that you'll use it for scientific and exploratory purposes that align with our institutional mission.
